Articles.Content:
Is there a rough guide to the maximum ore concentrations on various bodies?  I found a post with people saying they'd found over 11% on Minmus, but that's all I can find on the forum.

So far my scans reckon a 6.something% average for the Mun highlands, and my rover has found a shade over 8%, there's a flat area not far from the 8% find so I'll probably put the base there but interested to know if there's likely to anything much higher than I'm missing.
Check if you forget difficulty setting - there's a global multiplier adjustable when a game starts, notably moderate difficulty has a 80% multiplier.
Didn't know that.  I'm just on the default settings.

8 hours ago, RizzoTheRat said:

Is there a rough guide to the maximum ore concentrations on various bodies?  I found a post with people saying they'd found over 11% on Minmus, but that's all I can find on the forum.

Remember, the concentrations of ore in the various biomes of any planet get randomized every time you start a new game.  Thus, it's never QUITE the same for any 2 players, or even the same player in 2 different games.  And as @FancyMouse says, the difficulty setting makes a difference.

Otherwise, observations from playing (and poking around in the Ore.cfg file) indicate the following general things...

  • The sun, Jool, and all oceans are hard-coded to have zero ore
  • Elsewhere, ore concentrations are based on biomes.  IOW, Biome A has some average concentration no matter where that biome appears on the planet, while Biome B has a different concentration.
  • On any given planet, the biomes with the highest ore concentrations tend to be 1) those with the highest terrain elevations (mountains, highlands) 2) the poles, and 3) those with the lowest terrain elevations (Minmus flats, lowlands, crater bottoms), in that order.  Although there are exceptions.  Biomes with medium terrain elevations (which usually make up the majority of the surface) tend to have negligible ore concentrations.
  • Within a given biome, the ore concentration may vary slightly from place to place.  This usually follows the same elevation trend as the biomes themselves.  IOW, if the lowlands have a relatively high concentration for the planet, then the lowest places within the lowlands biome will usually have slightly higher concentrations than the rest of the lowlands.
  • Planets with more dirt/stone/metal in their make-up tend to have higher concentrations in all their biomes than do icy planets.  IOW, the best concentrations on Dres will be average or poor compared to what you usually find on Mun.
  • The maximum concentration you'll find in any biome without >100% abundance setting is 15%.  But I've never found more than about 11% once in a while.  Usually, 8-9% is the best you'll see, and even that is fairly uncommon.  Mostly, you'll find 1-3% unless you do a bit of prospecting.

Of course, even with those guidelines, you still have to prospect.  And don't expect to exploit the highest concentrations on any given planet because those are usually in very inconvenient, even inaccessible, places (mountains and poles).  What you usually end up with is the highest concentration available in a convenient location.  Convenience means on reasonably flat ground and usually on or near the equator, depending on local gravity and the dV cost of inclination changes.

The 1st thing you need to do is get a biome map of the planet.  If you don't have SCANsat, then you have to use the ALT-F12 menu to display biomes in the map view.  Then you need to determine the ore concentrations in the convenient biomes by prospecting with the Surface Scanner and/or NBS (or use SCANsat with stock resource scanning disabled).  Then pick the best biomes that are conveniently located and scout them out on the ground for a flat place to build your base on.

I wrote a tutorial on the whole prospecting process.  The link is in my sig.
Yeah, I found your prospecting tutorial after I posted, which has taught me how to use the scanners and Scansat properly, thanks.  Have settled on a 10% patch.

Another factor I have noticed:

1) Wherever you do the 'calibration' test using the surface ore scanner?  That location will always be exactly the value claimed as 'average'.

2) On a large biome, you can usually see some variation in ore concentration from the orbital scanner even before calibration.

Thus:

Find what looks like the lowest concentration on the low rez orbital map, and calibrate the ore concentrations from that spot.  Everywhere else should then be even higher value!

1 hour ago, suicidejunkie said:

Wherever you do the 'calibration' test using the surface ore scanner?  That location will always be exactly the value claimed as 'average'.

This one thing has always been the piece of mining/prospecting that causes cognitive dissonance for me.  It makes no sense to me.  Clearly my mental model about how all of this works must be wrong somehow, but I've never been able to figure out what I'm doing wrong.

My (apparently incorrect) mental model goes like this:

  1. I do an orbital scan
  2. This gives very low-res information: basically, what's the average concentration for each biome
  3. But the concentration within a biome actually varies, so I need higher-res information
  4. So I land a probe and do an ore sample
  5. This "unlocks" the biome and now I can see actual concentration for where I am

...So unless I just happen to get "lucky" and land on a spot whose ore concentration is exactly what the biome's average is, I should expect the number to change after I do the sample, right?  i.e. before I do the sample, it's just telling me what the biome's average is, but after I do the sample, it's telling me what's the actual concentration at the spot where I am.  Right?

So why does the number not change?

I'm very confused.  What does that number mean?  And what is the actuall difference between before-sample and after-sample?  (I can't tell that the orbital resource map looks all that much different from before and after doing the sample.)

As far as I can tell, you are changing the planet to match what your sensor reads, rather than vice versa.

It is a subtle, but profound difference.

1 hour ago, suicidejunkie said:

As far as I can tell, you are changing the planet to match what your sensor reads, rather than vice versa.

It is a subtle, but profound difference.

Certainly, it kinda feels that way... but my brain just rebels at the notion.  Surely not?!

There must be something I'm missing, here.

8 hours ago, suicidejunkie said:

Another factor I have noticed:

1) Wherever you do the 'calibration' test using the surface ore scanner?  That location will always be exactly the value claimed as 'average'.

I disagree.  In general, a given biome's ore will be pretty uniform throughout, due to that's how ore works.  However, within that biome, the exact concentration under your feet will vary with terrain elevation.  Put both a Surface Scanner and an NBS on the same rrover and see for yourself.

12 minutes ago, Geschosskopf said:

I disagree.  In general, a given biome's ore will be pretty uniform throughout, due to that's how ore works.  However, within that biome, the exact concentration under your feet will vary with terrain elevation.  Put both a Surface Scanner and an NBS on the same rrover and see for yourself.

Fair 'nuff, but I gotta say... I don't think I've ever seen the number change when I click the button to do the surface-sample thing.  No change, even in the hundredths-of-a-percent.  All that changes is that the "avg" goes away.

28 minutes ago, Snark said:

Fair 'nuff, but I gotta say... I don't think I've ever seen the number change when I click the button to do the surface-sample thing.  No change, even in the hundredths-of-a-percent.  All that changes is that the "avg" goes away.

The Surface Scanner readout displays the average for the biome it's in and the specific concentration directly under your ship which may differ somewhat depending on terrain elevation within that biome.  If you move it around within that biome, the average will stay the same but the specific will change if you go up or down a high enough elevation change.

The best results are obtained by putting both the Surface Scanner and the NBS on the same vehicle.  Once you "run analysis" with the Surface Scanner, the NBS will show varied ore concentrations over that biome within its range.  Find the highest local concentration on the NBS map, drive or fly the vehicle to that neighborhood, and use the Surface Scanner to tell you when you're standing right on the highest concentration.

1 minute ago, Geschosskopf said:

The Surface Scanner readout displays the average for the biome it's in and the specific concentration directly under your ship which may differ somewhat depending on terrain elevation within that biome.  If you move it around within that biome, the average will stay the same but the specific will change if you go up or down a high enough elevation change.

Right, so let's say I haven't done the surface scan yet, and the gizmo is telling me "6.38% avg".

And then I press the button to take a surface scan, and now it says "6.38%".

Am I to understand that this means that the average for the whole biome is 6.38%, and also that the particular concentration right at this spot is also exactly 6.38%?  Shouldn't I expect to see the number go up a little or down a little (at least sometimes), given that biomes have variation within themselves?

9 hours ago, Snark said:

Right, so let's say I haven't done the surface scan yet, and the gizmo is telling me "6.38% avg".

And then I press the button to take a surface scan, and now it says "6.38%".

Am I to understand that this means that the average for the whole biome is 6.38%, and also that the particular concentration right at this spot is also exactly 6.38%?  Shouldn't I expect to see the number go up a little or down a little (at least sometimes), given that biomes have variation within themselves?

Hmmm, it works a bit differently for me.  Maybe due to SCANsat being installed?  I dunno.

Anyway, for me, the Surface Scanner right-click menu has 2 lines displaying stuff about ore concentrations.  One up near the top (next to the lat/lon readout) that shows the concentration at that specific spot on the ground, and one at the very bottom that's the biome's average as a whole.  Both lines require that you have already done whatever type of orbital scan you're using in your game (stock or SCANsat of some sort) before they'll show useful data.

The top line (exact value at specific location) only shows up after you push the button to run analysis, and then it only remains displayed as long as the Surface Scanner is actually on the ground and still within the same biome.  If the vehicle leaves the ground, this line goes away, but returns when you land if you're still in the same biome.  If you move into a new biome, this line goes away and the analysis button reappears.  But after you've pushed the button, moving around on the ground within that same biome keeps this line displayed, and the value changes in real time as you move to show what's right under the vehicle.  However, ore concentration within a biome usually vary only slightly over a scale of kilometers so you usually have to move a fair distance to see much if any change in this display.

The lower line with the biome's average always displays but what the line says depends on whether you're using stock scanning or SCANsat (and how you set up SCANsat if using that).  With stock, the average is unknown until you run analysis.  With SCANsat, if you've already mapped resources from orbit, the biome average will display from the get-go.

Because ore concentrations usually vary only slightly over a distance of kilometers within a given biome, usually once you push the analysis button, the specific and average values are often the same or very close.  This is where the NBS comes in.  Again, this differs depending on whether you're using stock or SCANsat.  With stock, the NBS display will only show biome averages until you run analysis with the surface scanner in that biome.  Once you do that, the NBS display will show location-specific concentrations at all  points within that biome.  With SCANsat, the stock NBS display is replaced with the standard SCANsat zoom window from the big map and will show location-specific values from the get-go.  Anyway, bring up the NBS display and mouse over it to see if there are any local hotspots around.  Note their coordinates and directions from your current location, then go there, keeping an eye on the surface scanner's location-specific display to know when you've arrived.

I've finally gotten around to doing some science on this, but I've installed scansat since, so it isn't stock resource mapping.  But in this situation, I found three biomes where calibrating caused the surface scanner % value to change.
